editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The second part of the iron age which containeth the death of Penthesilea, Paris Priam, and Hecuba: the burning of Troy: the deaths of Agamemnon, Menelaus, Clytaemnestra, Helena, Orestes, Aegisthus, Pylades, King Diomed, Pyrrhus, Cethus, Sinon, Thersites, etc. written by Thomas Heywood.
Printed at London by Nicholas Okes. 1632.

list.head: New persons not presented in the former part of this history.
list.item: Sinon a perjure Greek, by whose tears Troy was set on fire.
Chorebus a prince, who came to the wars for the love of Cassandra.
Polites, a young son of King
A Trojan citizen. And his wife.
Penthesilea Queen of the Amazons, with her train of viragoes.
Cethus' son to King naulus, and brother of Palamedes.
Orestes son to King Agamemnon, and his Queen Clytaemnestra.
Clytaemnestra wife and Queen to Agamemnon.
Aegisthus a favourite to Queen Clytaemnestra.

div.head: To the reader.
div.p:
Courteous reader: I commend unto thee an entire history, from Jupiter and Saturn, to the utter subversion of Troy ▪ with a faithful account of the deaths of all these princes of Greece, who had hand in the fate thereof, (Ulysses only excepted, to whom belongeth a further history.) Read freely, and censure favourably. These ages have been long since writ, and suited with the time then: I know not how they may be received in this age, where nothing but satirica Dictaeria, and comica scommata are now in request: for mine own part, I never affected either ▪ when they stretched to the abuse of any person public, or private. If the three former ages (Now out of print,) be added to these (As I am promised) to make up an handsome volume; I purpose (Deo assistente,) to illustrate
the whole work, with an explanation of all he difficulties, and an historical comment of every hard name, which may appear obscure or intricate to such as are not frequent in poetry: which (As the rest) I shall freely devote to thy favourable perusal, in this as all the rest industrious to thy pleasure and profit:

div.head: To my worthy and much respected friend, Mr. Thomas Mannering esquire.
div.p:
And my much respected friend: the impression of your love, after so many years acknowledgement, enforceth me that I cannot choose, but in my best recollection, to number you in the file and list of my best and choicest wellwishers. True it is, that my unable merit hath ever come much short of your ample acknowledgement: howsoever, though you be now absent in the country, upon a necessary retirement; yet let this witness in my behalf, that you are not altogether unremembered in the city: nor take it unkindly at my hands that I have reserved your name to the catastrophe and conclusion of this work: since being scoena novissima,
it must be consequently the fresher in memory; as you have had ever a charitable and indulgent censure of such poor pieces of mine, as have come accidentally unto your view. So I entreat you now, (As one better able to judge, than I to determine) to receive into your favourable patronage, this second part of the iron age. I much deceive myself, if i heard you not once commend it, when you saw it acted; if you persist in the same opinion, when you shall spare some sorted hours to hear it read, in your pains, I shall hold myself much pleased: over remaining

closer.signed: Yours, not to be changed: Thomas Heywood.

body.head: The second part of the iron age: with the destruction of Troy.

div.stage: Enter Agamemnon, Menelaus, Ulysses, Diomed, Thersites. Drum, colours, soldiers, etc.

sp.speaker: Agamemnon.
sp.l: Ye terrors of the Asian monarchy,
And Europe's glory: warlike lords of Greece:
Although the great prince of the Myrmidons,
And armstrong Aiax, our best champions,
Be by the gods bereft us: yet now comes
A phoenix out of their cold ashes rising:
Pyrrhus, surnamed Neoptolemus:
On whom for his deceased father's sake,
We must bestow some honours. Menelaus,
Ulysses, Diomed, give the prince meeting,
And be his conduct to the general.

div.stage: A flourish. Enter the Kings before named, bringing in Pyrhus, Synon, with attendants.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Pyrrhus kneel down, we girt thee with this sword,
it was thy fathers. In his warlike hand
It hath cleft Trojans to the navel down,
Pared heads off faster than the harvest scythe
Doth the thin stalks, or bending ears of grain:
Wear it, and draw it to revenge his death.
Princes, perform your several ceremonies.

sp.speaker: Di●..
sp.l: These golden spurs I fasten to thine heels,
The same thy warlike father won in field,
When Hector tide with thongs to his steeds fetlocks,
Was dragged about the high built walls of Troy.

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: This armour, and this plumed burgonet,
In which thy father, like a rampired wall,
Opposed the fury of his enemies,
(By general consent of all these princes
Attributed to me) lo I surrender
To youthful Neoptolemus, wear it prince,
Not all the world yields a more strong defence.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Achilles tent, his treasure, and his jewels,
We have reserved, enjoy them noble Pyrrhus;
And lastly his strong guard of Myrmidons,
And with the honour he with these have won,
His sword, spurs, armour, guard, pauileon,
Be by his valiant son much dignified.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Before I touch the handle of his sword,
Or to my knightly spurs direct my eyes,
Lace this rich armour to my youthful sides,
Or roof mine head within this warlike tent,
Make proof of this his plumed burgonet,
Or take on me the leading of his guard:
Witness you Grecian princes, what I vow:
By Saturn's son, the sire of Aeacus,
Begotten on fair Europa; by their issue,
The second judge, placed on the infernal bench
I will descend to Peleus, and from him,
Even to my natural father, with whose honours
I join my mother Deidamia's
And in my vengeful oath include them all,
till Priam be compelled to shut his gates
For want of men: I'll be as merciless
As untamed lions, and the flesh-fed bears,
Blood shall look brighter in young Pyrrhus eyes
Then dissolved crystal, till old Priam's hairs
Be died in gore: till Hecub's reverent locks
Be beguiled in slaughter; all their sons and daughters,
Subjects, and city quite confused in ruin,
Bow to our merciless fury: I'll not leave
This black and fatal siege; and this I swear
As I am prince, and great Achilles' heir.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Even in thy looks I read the sack of Troy,
And Priam's tragedy: welcome sweet Pyrrhus,
And welcome you his warlike followers.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Where be these Trojans? I would fain behold
Their winged battalions grapple? I would see
The battered centre fly about their ears
In clouds of dust: I would have horses hooves
Beat thunder out of earth: the chariot trees
I would see drowned in blood, Scamander plains
O'erspread with entrails baked in blood and dust:
With terror I would have this day as black,
As when Hyperion leaping from his sphere,
Cast ugly darkness from his chariot wheels,
And in this veiled confusion the faint Trojans
Beat back into the town: I'd see their gates
Entered, and fire by their high battlements
Climbing towards heaven: the pavement of th'streets
I'd see paved o'er with faces: infants tossed
On lances points: big-bellied ladies flung
From out their casements: I'd have all their souls
Set upon wings, and Troy, no Troy, but fire,
As if ten thousand comets joined in one,
To close the world in red confusion.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Well spoke bold Sinon; and my lords of Greece,
This fellow boasts no more than with his sword,
He will adventure for, and should that fail,
he'll set his brain to work. I tell you princes,
My grandsire Lycomedes hath made proof
Of Sinon's policies, state-quaking projects
Are handmaidens to his brain; and he hath spirit
To drive his plots even to the door of death,
With rare effects, and then not all the world
Affords a villain more incomparable,
Than Sinon my attendant. Warlike princes,
I speak this to his praise: and I profess
Myself as stern, bloody, and merciless.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: I have not heard a braver character
Given to a Greek: and had he but my railing ▪
He were a man complete.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Sure there is something
Above a common man in yond same fellow,
Whom nature hath so marked, and were his mind
As crooked as his body, he were one
I could be much in love with.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: He hath a feature
That I could court, nay will: I would not lose
His friendship and acquaintance for the world.
Methinks you are a comely gentleman.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: I ever held myself so: and mine eye
Gives you no less: of all the Grecians here
Thou hast a face like mine, that fears no weather ▪
A shape that war itself cannot deform:
I best love such complexions.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: By the gods
We have two meeting souls: be my sweet urchin ▪

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: I will,
An thou shalt be mine ugly toad.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: A match: be we hence forth brothers and friends.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Embrace then friend and brother: my dear toad ▪

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: My amiable urchin.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I long for work, will not these Trojans come,
To welcome Pyrrhus, great Achilles son?

sp.speaker: Vlyss.
sp.l: Their drums proclaim them ready for the field.

div.stage: Enter Priam, Paris, Penthesilea, and her train of viragoes, Aeneas, Chorebus, Laocoon, Anthenor, etc.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Perhaps King Priam hath not yet related
The news of Neoptolemus arrive,
That he presumes thus, weakened as he is,
To open his gates, and meet us in the field.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: 'Tis like he hath, because for want of men
He brings a troop of women to the field:
Most sure he thinks, we (Like our warlike father)
Will be ensnared with beauty: Priam no,
We for his death, are sworn vain beauty's foe.

sp.speaker: Penth.
sp.l: Art thou Achilles' son, beneath whose hand
Assisted by his bloody Myrmidons,
The valiant Hector fell?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Woman I am.

sp.speaker: Penth.
sp.l: Thou shouldst be then a coward.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Penth.
sp.l: Even so:
Thy father was a foe dishonourable ▪
And so the world reputes him.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: By all the gods —

sp.speaker: Pent.
sp.l: Swear not, for ere the closure of the battle,
If both the generals please, with my good sword,
In single combat I'll make good my word.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: O that thou wert a man! but women's tongues
Are privileged: come Priam, all his sons,
The whole remain of fifty, I'll make good
My father's honour 'gainst sufficient odds.
But for these scolds, we leave them to their sex ▪
What make they amongst trojans.

sp.speaker: Penth.
sp.l: Scorn not proud Pyrrhus
Our presence in the field; I tell thee prince,
I am a Queen, the Queen of Amazons,
A warlike nation disciplined in arms.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Are you those harlots famous through the world,
that have usurped a kingdom to your selves,
And pent your sweet hearts in a barren isle,
Where your adulterate sports are exercised.

sp.speaker: Pent.
sp.l: Curb thy irregular tongue: we are those women
That practise arms, by which we purchase fame.
All the year long, only three months excepted,
Those wherein Phoebus drives his chariot,
In height of splendour through the burning cancer,
The fiery lion, and the virgin's sign:
Then we forsake our sunburnt continent,
And in a cooler clime, sport with our men,
And then return ▪ if we have issue male,
We nurse them up, then send them to their fathers.
If females, we then keep them, and with irons
Their right paps we sear off, with better ease
To couch their spears, and practise feats of arms.
We are those women, who expelled our land
By Egypt's tyrant: conquered Asia,
Egypt and Cappadocia: these two ladies
Descend from Menelippe and Hyppolita,
Who in Antiope's reign ▪ fought hand to hand
With Hercules and Theseus; we are those
That came for love of Hector to the field,
And (Being murdered) to revenge his death.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Then welcome Amazonians, as I live
I love you though I hate you: but beware,
Hate will outweigh my love, and I'll not spare
Your ●usl ind squadrons: for my father's fall,
Trojans, and Amazonians perish all.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Now Queen of Amazons, by the strong spirit
Achilles left his son, I let thee know
My father was an honourable foe.

sp.speaker: Pent.
sp.l: Defiance Pyrrhus, I'll to death proclaim,
Hector was by Achilles basely slain:
And on his son's head, with my keen edged sword,
And thundring strokes, I will make good my word.

div.stage: Alarum. They are both wounded, and divided by the two armies, who confusedly come betwixt them: to Pyrhus enter Agamemnon, Ulysses, and Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: What? wounded noble Pyrrhus?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Wounded? no,
I have not met one that can raze the skin
Of great Achilles' son.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Yet blood drops from your arm.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Not possible!
'Tis sure the blood of some slain enemy.
Come let's us break into the battles centre,
And to't pell-mell .

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: But Neoptolemus,
We prize thy safety more than all advantage:
Retire thyself to have thy wounds bound up,

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Coward's fear death,
I'll venge my blood, though with the loss of breath.
Art thou a madman fellow, that adventure
So near the blood of Neoptolemus,
Whose smallest drop must cost a Trojans life.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Art thou the bleeding issue of that Greek?
Ay, in revenge of noble Hector's death,
Slew in Apollo's temple.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Art thou then
That coward and effeminate Trojan boy.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Arm wounded Greek, I slew the false Achilles,
An act which I am proud of.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Fall on the murderer,
And flake him smaller than the Lybian sand.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: If any but myself offer one blow,
I'll on the Trojans party oppose him.
Come Paris, though against the odds of breath,
Achilles wounded son, will venge his death.

div.stage: Paris is slain by Pyrhus. A retreat sounded.
Enter then King Diomed, and Synon.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Why sound the Trojans this retreat?

sp.speaker: Syn
sp.l: Paris is slain, and Penthesilea
Wounded by Pyrrhus.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Come then Sinon
Go with me to my tent, this night we'll revel
With beauteous Cressida.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Not I, I hate all women, painted beauty
And I am opposites: I love thee less
Because thou dotest on Trojan Cressida.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: She's worthy of our love: I tell thee Sinon,
She is both constant, wise, and beautiful.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: She's neither constant, wise, nor beautiful,
I'll prove it Diomed: four elements
Meet in the structure of that Cressida,
Of which there's not one pure: she's compact
Merely of blood, of bones and rotten flesh,
Which makes her leprous, where the sun exhales
The moist complexion, it doth putrify
The region of th'air: there's than another,
Sometimes the sun sits muffled in his cave,
Whilst from the clouds fly hideous showers of rain,
Which sweeps the earth's corruption into brooks,
Brooks into rivers, rivers send their tribute,
As they receive it to their sovereign
The seething ocean: thus earth, air, and water,
Are all infected, she then framed of these,
Can she be beautiful? No Diomed,
If they seem fair, they have the help of art,
By nature they are ugly.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Leave this detraction.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Now for this Cressida's wisdom, is she wise,
Who would forsake her birthright, her brave friend,
The constant Troilus, for King Diomed;
To trust the faith of Greeks, and to love thee
That art to Troy a professed enemy?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Canst thou disprove her constancy?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: I can.
Never was woman constant to one man:
For proof, do thou but put into one scale
A feather, in the other Cressida's truth,
The feather shall down weigh it: Diomed
Wilt thou believe me, if I win not Cressid
To be my sweet heart: yet have no such face,
No such proportion, to bewitch a lady ▪
I never practised courtship, but am blunt;
Nor can I file my tongue: yet if I win not
The most chaste woman, I will cut it out.
Shall I make proof with her?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: There she comes,
Affront her Sinon, I'll withdraw unseen ▪

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: A gallant lady, who but such a villain ▪
As Sinon would betray her: but my vow
Is past, for she's a Trojan. Cressida,
You are well encountered: whether away sweet lady?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: To meet with kingly Diomed, and with kisses
Conduct him to his tent.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: 'Tis kindly done:
You love King Diomed then?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: As mine own life.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: What seest thou in him that is worth thy love ▪

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: He's of a fair and comely personage.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Personage? ha, ha.
I prithee look on me ▪ and view me well,
And thou wilt find some difference.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: True, more odds
Twixt him and thee, then betwixt Mercury
And limping Vulcan.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Yetas' fair a blowse
As you, sweet lady, wedded with that smith ▪
And bedded too, a black complexion
Is always precious in a woman's eye:
Leave Diomed, and love me Cressida.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Thee.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Me.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Deformity forbear, I will to Diomed
Make known thine insolence.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: I care not, for I, not desire to live,
If not beloved of Cressida: tell the King
If he stood by, I would not spare a word.
For thine own part, rare goddess, I adore thee,
And owe thee divine reverence: Diomed
Indeed's Aetolians King, and hath a Queen.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: A Queen?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: A Queen, that shall hereafter question thee:
Or canst thou think he loves thee really
Being a Trojan, but for present use:
Can Greeks love Trojans, are they not all sworn
To do them outrage?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: How canst thou then love me?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: I am a politician, oaths with me
Are but the tools I work with, I may break
An oath by my profession. Hear me further,
Thinkest thou King Diomed, forgets thy breach
Of love with Troilus? Ay or that he hopes
Thou canst be constant to a second friend,
That wast so false unto thy first beloved.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Synon thou art deceived thou knowest I never
Had left prince Troilus, but by the command
Of my old father Calchas.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Then love Diomed;
Yes, do so still, but Cressid mark the end ▪
If ever he transport thee to Aetolia,
His Queen will bid thee welcome with a vengeance:
Hast thou more eyes than these? she'll fall to work ▪
For such another vixen thou ne'er knewest ▪
Come Cressida be wise.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Love me, love Sinon.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Sinon loves not me ▪

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: I'll swear I do.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: I heard thee say, that thou wouldst break thine oath ▪

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Then I'll not swear, because I will not break it:
But yet I love thee Cressida, love me,
I'll leave the wars unfinished, Troy unsack;
And to my native country bear thee hence:
Nay wench I'll do't; come kiss me Cressida.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Well, you may use your pleasure;
But good Sinon keep this from Diomed.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: O perjured strumpet,
Is this thy faith? now Sinon I'll believe
There is no truth in women.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Am I betrayed? o thou base ugly villain,
I'll pull thine eyes out.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Ha, ha, King Diomed,
Did I not tell thee what thy sweet heart was.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Thou art a traitor to all woman kind.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: I am, and naught more grieves me then to
Think, a woman was my mother.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: A villain.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: A devil.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Little better.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Go get you back to Troy, away, begone,
You shall no more be my companion.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: And now fair Trojan weather-hen adieu ▪
And when thou next lovest, think to be more true ▪

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: O all you powers, above look down and see ▪
How I am punished for my perjury.

div.stage: Alarum. Enter Penthesilea with her Amazonians.

sp.speaker: Penth.
sp.l: Stay, what sad lady's this? whence are you woman?
Of Troy or Greece?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: I was of Troy till love drew me from thence,
But since have sojourned in the tents of Greece,
with Diomed King of Aetolia:
O had I never known him.

sp.speaker: Pent.
sp.l: Would you trust
You honour amongst strangers? but sweet lady
Discourse your wrongs.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: I was betrayed:
It shames me to relate the circumstance,
By a false Greek, one that doth hate our sex,
One Sinon, if you meet him in the battle,
I with my tears entreat you be revenged.

sp.speaker: Pent.
sp.l: How might we know him?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: His visage swart, and earthy o'er his shoulder
Hangs locks of hair, black as the raven's plumes:
His eyes down looking, you shall hardly see
One in whose shape appears more treachery.

sp.speaker: Pent.
sp.l: We lose much time: lady haste you to Troy,
And if we meet a fellow in the battle
Of your description, by our honoured names,
We'll have his blood to recompense our shames.

sp.speaker: Amaz.
sp.l: By her description this should be the man

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Compassed with smocks and long coats:
Now you whores.

sp.speaker: Pent.
sp.l: Is thy name Sinon?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: No, but I know Sinon.
He is my friend and brother.

sp.speaker: Ama.
sp.l: For Sinon's sake, prepare thyself for slaughter ▪

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: He ▪ who names Sinon?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Brother thou ne'er couldst come in better time:
See, see, how I am rounded.

sp.speaker: Pent.
sp.l: Were ever such a pair of devil's seen?
They are so like, they needs must be allied.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: What can their dams say to us?

sp.speaker: Pent.
sp.l: You betray ladies, envy all our sex,
And that you now shall pay for girt him round.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: I recant nothing, 〈◊〉 me sweet faced brother:
and now you witches ▪ varlets, drabs, and queans,
We'll cut you all to fragments.

div.stage: Alarum. Synon and Thersites beaten off by the Amazons. Pyrhus enters, fights with Penthesilea, after this a retreat sounded, then enters Menelaus, Agamemnon, Ulysses, Diomed.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: The Trojans sound retreat.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: Who saw young Pyrrhus?

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: I fear his too much rage hath spurred him on
Too far amongst the Amazonian troops.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Why stand you idle here, and let the Trojans
Lead warlike Pyrrhus prisoner to the town.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: How Pyrrhus prisoner?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: We saw him compassed by the Amazous:
Penthesilea with her bustain troops.
Laid load upon his helm.

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: Then this retreat
Upon the sudden argues that they lead him
Captive to Troy.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Courage brave princes, I have got a prize
Worthy the purchase, on my lance's point
Sits perched the Amazonians lopped off head,
Upon my warlike sword her bleeding arm,
At sight of which the Trojans sound retreat:
The honour of this day belongs to us.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: To none but Neoptolemus.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Sinon you played the coward: so Thersites.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: If not so.
I had not lived to see Troy's overthrow

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: When didst thou ever see a villain valiant?
What's past remember not, but what's to come:
Priam hath shut his gates, and will no more
Meet him in arms: can you with all your valour
Glide through the walls, if not what are you nearer
For all your ten years siege?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: 'Tis true, some stratagem to enter Troy
Were admirable: for princes till I see
The temple burn wherein my father died,
And Troy no Troy but ashes; my revenge
Will have no stern aspect, till I behold
Troy's ground-sils swim in pools of crimson gore
Ramnusia's altar filled with flowing helms
Of blood and brains: Priam and Hecuba
Dragged by this hand to death, and this my sword
Ravish the breast of fair Polixena,
I shall not think my father's death revenged.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: To him that can contrive
A stratagem by which to enter Troy,
I'll give the whole spoil of Apollo's temple.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: I my rich tent.

sp.speaker: Ulis.
sp.l: I the Palladium that I brought from Troy.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: I all my birthright in Aetolia.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Peace, 'tis here: I have't.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I'll hug thee Sinon.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Touch me not, away:
There 're more hammers beating in my brain
Then ever touched Vulcan's anvil, more ideas
Than atoms, embryons innumerable ▪
Growing to perfect shape; and now 'tis good.
Call for Endymion's bastard, where's Epeus?
I'll set him straight a work.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Upon some engine Sinon.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: A horse, a horse.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Ten kingdoms for a horse to enter Troy.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Stay, let me see:
Ulysses you have the Palladium.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: I have so.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Call for Epeus then, the general
Hath no command in him.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Let's know the project.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: And that Palladium stood in Pallas temple,
And consecrate to her.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: It did so.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Call for Epeus then.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Let's hear what thou intendest.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: I'll have an horse built with so huge a bulk,
As shall contain a thousand men in arms.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: And enter Troy with that?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Do't you, you trouble mine invention,
I am grown muddy with your interruption:
Good young man lend more patience, hear me out:
This engine framed, and stuffed with armed greeks.
(Will you take down your tents, march back to Tenedos?)

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: What shall the horse do then?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Not gallop as your tongue doth: good Ulysses
Lend me your apprehension; when the Trojans
Find you are gone aboard, they'll straight suppose
You'll not weigh anchor: till the gods inform you
Of your success at sea: if then a villain
Can drive into their ears, the goddess Pallas
Offended for her stolen Palladium:
(Will you erect this machine to her honour?)
Withal that were it brought into her temple,
It would retain the gilt Palladium's virtue.
Might not the forged tale move aged Priam,
To hale this engine presently to Troy,
Pull down his walls for entrance, leave a breach
Where in the dead of night, all your whole army
May enter, take them sleeping in their beds,
And put them all to sword.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: 'Tis rare!

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: 'Tis admirable, I will adventure
My person in the horse.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Do so, and get a thousand spirits more.
King Agamemnon, if you like the project,
Down with your tent.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Sinon, we will,

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: I'll set a light upon the walls of Troy
Shall give the summons when you shall return ▪
about it princes: Pyrrhus get you men
In readiness, I will expose myself
To bewitch Priam with a weeping tale,
I cannot to the life describe in words,
What I'll express in action.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Down with our tents.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I'll to pick out bold Greeks to fill the horse:
Shine bright you lamps of heaven, for ere't be long
We'll dim your radiant beams with flaming lights
And bloody meteors, from Troy's burning streets.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Such sights are glorious sparks in Sinon's eyes,
Who longs to feast the devil with tragedies.

div.head: Actus secundus: scoena prima.

sp.speaker: Aeneas'
sp.l: The Grecians gone?

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: All their tents raised, their ten years siege removed ▪
Now Troy may rest securely.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: They may report at their return to Greece
The welcome they have had: what have they won?
But wounds, time's loss, shame, and confusion.

div.stage: Enter K. Priam, Anthenor, young Polytes, Polixena, Hecuba, and Hellen, with attendance.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: We now are lord of our own territories,
Ten years kept from us by th'invading Greeks ▪
Now we may freely take a full survey
Of all Scamander plain, drunk with the mixture
Of th'opposite bloods of Trojans and of Greeks.

sp.speaker: Hecu.
sp.l: And royal husband we have cause to joy,
That after so long siege the Greeks are f●ed,
And you in peace may rest your aged head.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Upon this east-side stood Ulysses tent,
The politic Greek.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: There was old Nestor's quarter,
And Agamemnon's that; the general.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: Upon the north-side of the field, Achilles
That bloody Greek pitched, and upon this plain,
I well remember, was my Hector slain.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: This empty place being South from all the rest,
The valiant Diomed hath oft made good,
And here, even here, his rich pavilion stood.

sp.speaker: Hecu.
sp.l: But here, even here, near to Duke Aiax tent,
Round girt with Myrmidon, my Troilus fell.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Then was this place a standing lake of blood,
Part of which moisture the bright sun exhaled;
And part the thirsty earth hath quaffed to Mars:
But now the swords on either part are sheathed,
And after ten years tumults wars surcease,
They lading their ships home with shameful peace.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: For which we'll praise the gods, banquet and feast,
Since by their flight, our glorious fame's increased.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Soft, what huge engine's that left on the strand,
That bears the shape and figure of an horse.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: What, shall we hew it piecemeal with our swords?

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: O be not rash, sure 'tis some mystery
That this great architecture doth include.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: But mine opinion is, this steeds huge bulk
Is stuffed with Greekish guile.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: I rather think
It is some monumental edifice
Unto the goddess Pallas consecrate:
Then spare your fury.

sp.speaker: La●.
sp.l: Why stand you gazing at this horrid craft,
Forged by the fly Ulysses, is his brain
unknown in Troy? or can you look for safety
From those who ten years have besieged your walls?
Either this huge swollen bulk is big with soldiers,
Longing to be delivered of armed Greeks,
Whose monstrous fatal and abhorred birth,
Will be Troy's ruin: else this hill of timber
This horselike structure stabled up in Troy,
Will spurn down these our walls, our towers demolish,
Which it shall never: come you Trojan youth
That love the public safety, no proud Greek
Upon this steeds back, o'er 'Troy's wall shall ride.
First with this javelin I'll transpierce his side.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: What means Laocoon?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Princes stay his fury.

sp.speaker: Lao.
sp.l: Hark Trojans, if a jarring noise of arms,
Sighed not throw these deep caverns, I divine
This gluttonous womb hath swallowed a whole band
Of men in steel, then with your swords and glaves
Rip up his tough sides, and embowel him,
That we may prove how they have lined his entrails.

div.stage: Enter two soldiers bringing in Synon bound.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Stay, and proceed, no further in your rage,
Till we have learned some novel from this Greek,
Whom in a ditch we found fast gyved and bound.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: Laocoon cease thy violence till we know
From that poor Grecian, what that machine means.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: O me, (Of all on earth most miserable,)
Whom neither heavens will succour, earth preserve,
Nor seas keep safe, ay, whom the heavens despise,
The earth abandons, and the sea's disdain:
Where shall I shroud me? whom, but now the Greeks
Threatened with vengeance; and escaped from them,
Fallen now into the hands of Trojans, menacing death:
The world affords no place, to wretched Sinon,
Of comfort, for where ere I fix my foot,
I tread upon my grave: the four vast corners
Of this large universe, in all their rooms
And spacious emptiness, will not afford me
My body's length of rest: where ere I fly,
Or stay, or turn, death's th'object of mine eye!

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: What art thou? or whence comest thou? briefly speak?
Thou wretched man, thou movest us with thy tears:
Unbind him soldiers.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Shall I deny myself to be of Greece?
Because I am brought captive into Troy?
No Sinon cannot lie: heaven, earth, and sea,
From all which I am outcast, witness with me
That Sinon cannot lie: thrice damned Ulysses,
The black-haired Pyrrhus, and horned Menelaus
Crook-backed Thersites, luxurious Diomed,
And all the rabble of detested Greeks,
I call to witness, Sinon cannot lie.
Could I have oiled my tongue, and cringed my ham,
Suppled mine humble knee to crouch and bend,
Heaved at my bonnet, shrugged my shoulders thus,
Grinned in their faces, Sinon then had stood,
Whom now this hour must stew in his own blood.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: The perfect image of a wretched creature,
His speeches beg remorse.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: Alas good man,
Shake off the timorous fear of servile death,
Though 'mongst us Trojans, and thyself a Greek,
Thou art not now amongst thine enemies,
Thy life I'll warrant, only let us know
What this horse means.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Greece I renounce thee, thou hast thrown me off,
Fair Troy● am thy creature. Now I'll unrip
Ulysses craft, my fatal enemy.
Who sold to death the Duke Palamedes,
My kinsman Trojans (Though in garments torn)
Sinon stands here, yet is he nobly born:
For that known murder did I haint his tent
with railing menaces, horrible exclaims,
Many a black-saint, of wishes, oaths, and curses
Have I sung at his window, then demanding
Justice of Agamemnon, Diomed,
Duke Nestor with the other lords of Greece,
For murder of the prince Palamedes,
And being denied it in my most vexation,
My bitter tongue spared not to bark at them:
For this I was observed, looked through and through
Ulysses brain had marked me, for my tongue
And fatted me for death by Calchas means,
He wrought so far that I should have been offered
Unto the gods for sacrifice, the priest
Lifting his hand aloft to strike me dead,
I leapt down from the altar, and so fled,
Pursuit and search was made, but I lay safe
In a thick tuft of sedge, till I was found
By these your soldiers, who thus brought me bound.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: Thou now art free secured from all their tyrannies
Now tell us what's the meaning of this horse?
Why have they left him here, themselves being gone?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: My new released hands, thus I heave on high,
Witness you gods, that Sinon cannot lie,
But as a new adopted Trojan now
By Priam's grace; I here protest by Jove,
By these eternal fires that spangle heaven,
The altar, and that sacrificing sword,
Beneath whose stroke I lay, since my base country
Casts me away to death, I am now born
A son of Troy: not Hector whilst he lived
More damaged Greece by his all wounding arm,
Than I by my discovery: well, you know
How the Greeks honour Pallas, who incensed
Because Ulysses the Palladium stole
Out of her temple, and her warders slew,
In rage she threatened ruin to all Greece:
Therefore to her hath Calchas built this horse.
(Greece pardon me, and all my country gods
Be deaf to Sinon's tale, and let it be
Henceforth forgotten that I was born in Greece,
Lest times to come record what I reveal,
The black confusion of my native weal.

sp.speaker: Priam.
sp.l: And what's that Sinon?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Where left I? at the horse, built of that size,
Lest you should give it entrance at your gates:
For know should your rude hands dare to profane
This gift sacred to Pallas; rots and diseases,
Pests and infections shall depopulate you,
And in a small short season, they returning,
Shall see thy subjects slain, fair Troy bright burning.
I'm even with thee Ulysses, and my breath
Strikes all Greece home for my intended death.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: Thanks Sinon, we shall bounteously reward thee,

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: And see my liege, to make good his report,
Laocoon, he that with his javelin pierced
This gift of Pallas, round embraced with snakes,
That wind their trains about his wounded waist,
And for his late presumption sting him dead.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: We have not seen so strange a prodigy,
Laocoon hath offended all the gods,
In his profane attempt.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Then lend your helping hands,
To lift up that Pallad an monument
Into Troy's city: levers, cables, cords.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: It cannot enter through the city gates.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Down with the walls then.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: These walls that ten years have defended Troy,
For all their service shall we ruin them.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: But this shall not defend you for ten years,
But make your town impregnable for ever.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: Down with the walls then, each man lend a hand.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: I hear a noise of armour.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Ha, what's that?

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: I fear some treason in that horse enclosed:
nor will I lend an hand to hale him in.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Down with the walls.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: And Trojans now after your ten years toil,
Day's battles, the fields trouble, and night's watch,
This is the first of all your rest, feast, banquet, joy and play,
Pallas is ours, the Greeks sailed hence away.

sp.speaker: Pria.
sp.l: Here we release all sentries and commit
Our broken walls to her celestial guard:
We will reward thee Sinon, the Greeks gone,
Priam. may ● est his age, in his soft throne.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: So, so, so,
Synon I hope shall warm his hands anon,
At a bright goodly bonfire: here's the key
Unto this machine by Epeus built,
Which hath already with his brazen breast,
Tilted Troy's wall down, and anon being drunk
With the best blood of Greece, in dead of night
Having surcharged his stomach, will spew out
A thousand men in arms: sweet midnight come,
I long to mask me in thy sable wings,
That I may do some mischief and black deeds:
We shall have rare sport, admirable spoil,
Cutting of throats, with stabbing, wounding, killing
Some dead asleep , and some half sleep, half wakes
Some dancing antics in their bloody shirts,
To which their wives cries, and their infant's shrieks,
Play music, brave mirth, pleasing harmony:
Then having spit young children on our spears,
We'll roast them at the scorching flames of Troy:
Fly swift you winged minutes till you catch
That long-wished hour of stillness: in which Troy
Sleeps her last sleep, made drunk with wine and joy.
In the receiving of this fatal steed,
Sick Troy this day hath swallowed such a pill,
Shall search her entrails, and her ●ives blood spill.

div.stage: Enter Agamemnon, Menelaus, Ulysses, with soldiers in a soft march, without noise.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Soft, soft, and let your stillness suit with night,
Fair Phebe keep thy silver splendour in,
And be not seen tonight .

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Were Phebe in my case,
She soon would blush to show her horned face.

sp.speaker: Vliss.
sp.l: We would not have a star cast it's clear eye
On our dark enterprise: too fast: so, still.
Here ambush, till you see the flaming torch,
Sinon this night upon the walls of Troy,
Will toss about his ears, as a true signal,
The great Epean structure is received,
And we may find safe entrance by the breach.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: A stand, the word through all the regiment,

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: A stand.

div.stage: Enter Synon with a torch above.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Thy everlasting sleep sleep careless Troy,
This horrid night buried in wine and mirth,
This fatal horse spurred by the brain of Sinon,
Hath leapt o'er Troy's high bulwarks great with Greeks,
Four times in raising up the monument,
A shaking sound of armour harshly jarred
In all the prince's ears, and had they not
Been drunk in Sinon's tears, they'd found our guile.
It is now midnight. The black darkness fallen,
And rolled o'er all the world, as well the poles,
As the great ocean, and the earth: now's the time
For tragic slaughter, clad in gules and sables,
To spring out of hell's jaws, and play strange reaks
In sleepy Troy, this bright and flaming brand
Which I so often gyre about mine ears,
Is signal for the armies quick return,
And make proud Ilium like my bright torch burn,
Wink all you eyes of heaven, or you shall be
Bloodshot to view Troy's dismal tragedy.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: The signals on the war: forward brave soldiers,
The horse is entered, Sinon's tale believed.
And we this night shall see the sack of Troy.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: March on then, the black darkness covers us,
And we without suspicion easily may
Disperse ourselves about these high built walls:

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Now with a soft march enter at this breach
But give no token of a loud alarm,
Till we have met with Pyrrhus and the rest,
Whom the steed's bulk includes.

div.stage: They march softly in at one door, and presently in at another. Enter Synon with a stealing pa●e, holding the key in his hand.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Soft, soft, ay so, hereafter ages tell,
How Sinon's key unlocked the gates of hell.

div.stage: Pyrhus, Diomed, and the rest, leap from out the horse. And as if groping in the dark, meet with Agamemnon and the rest: who after knowledge embrace.

sp.speaker: Pyrhus.
sp.l: The general?

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Pyrrhus?

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Menelaus?

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Diomed?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: My urchin?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: What my toad?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Well met in Troy great lords.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: Where are we now?

sp.speaker: Sy.
sp.l: In the high street, near to the church of Pallas,
And this you past, the gate called Dardanus.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Then here begins Troy's fatal tragedy:
Princes of Greece, at once unsheathe your swords,
And hear protest with Neoptolemus,
By our forefather Peleus, grandam Thetis,
The imperious goddess of the sea, that made
Achilles, save in th'heel, invulnerable,
And by my father great Aeacides,
His glorious name, his armour which I wear,
his bloody wounds, and his black sepulchre;
I here abjure all respite, mercy, sleep,
Until this city be a place confused:
This mural girdle that begirts it round
A causeway for the Greeks to trample on,
The place a stone-heap swimming in an ocean
Of Trojan blood, which shall from far appear
Like an high rock in the red sea.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: A brave show,
To see full boats in blood of Trojans row,
And the poor labouring snakes with arms spread swims
In lukewarm blood of their allies and kin.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Whence must this ocean flow?
From thousand springs
Of gentle and ignoble, base and Kings.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Set on then, none retire;
Wave in the one hand steel, in the other fire.
Loud drums and trumpets ring Troy's fatal peal,
That now lies drawing on, the word be vengeance,
Alarum, at that watchword fire, and kill,
And wide-mouthed Orchus with whole legions fill ▪

div.stage: Aloud alarum. Enter a Trojan in his nightgown all unready.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: Was an alarum sure that frighted me
In my dead sleep, 'twas near the Dardan port:
Jove grant that all be well.

div.stage: Enter his wife as from bed.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O heaven! what tumult's this
That hurries through the fatal streets of Troy ▪
I fear some treason.

sp.speaker: Tro.
sp.l: Stay wife, lay thine ear
Unto the ground and list, if we can gather
Of what condition this strange uproar is
That riots at this late unseasoned hour?
Sure 'tis the noise of war, whence should it grow?
The Greeks are sailed hence, Troy needs fear no foe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: The horrid stir comes on this way towards us.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: O whither shall we turn?

div.stage: A great cry within. Alarum, enter Pyrhus with the rest their weapons draw and torches.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O save me husband.

sp.speaker: Troi.
sp.l: Succour me dear wife.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Vengeance for Greece and Neoptolemus.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: So fly the word along, die old and young,
Mourn Troy in ashes for Achilles' loss,
Steel in one hand, in th'other firebrands toss.

div.stage: Enter Chorebus at one door, at another Aeneas with their weapons drawn.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: This horrid clamour that hath called me up
From my deep rest, much, much amazeth me;
'Tis on the right hand, now upon the left,
It goes before me and it follows me:
O Jove expound the meaning of this horror
Which the dark midnight makes more terrible.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: This street is clear, but now I climbed a turret,
And I might well discern half Troy in fire,
And by the flame the burnished helmets glister
Of men in arms, whence Jove Olympic knows.

sp.speaker: 2. Tro.
sp.l: Where shall I hide me? Treason, Troy's betrayed;
The fatal horse was full of armed Greeks.

sp.speaker: Chore.
sp.l: Of Greeks? damned Sinon.

sp.speaker: 2. Tro.
sp.l: Prince Chorebus fly,
Fly great Aeneas.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Which way? where? or how?
Are we not rounded with a quickset hedge
Of pointed steel? are not the gates possessed
And strongly maned with Greeks? death everywhere ,
Then whither should we fly?

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Into the throng.
Where blows are dealt, where our inflamed turrets
burn with most fury.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Nobly speaks Aeneas.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Then whither flames, and furies, shrieks and clamours,
Death, danger, and the devils hurry us,
Thither will we: follow where I shall lead,
Thousands shall fall by us ere we be dead.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Charge on these naked Trojans, and cry thus,
Vengeance for Greece and Neoptolemus.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Charge on these armed Grecians, and thus cry,
We may yet live to see ten thousand die.
They charge the Greeks and kill them, Thersites runs away.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Well fought brave spirits in our utter ruin,
We are conquerors yet: let's don these Greekish habits,
And mix ourselves amongst their armed ranks;
So unexpected murder all we meet:
The darkness will assist our enterprise.
These Greekish arms this night by Trojans worn
Shall to the fall of many Grecians turn.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Burn fire, and kill, as you wound cry thus,
Vengeance for Greece and Neoptolemus.

div.stage: Enter Aeneas followed by Hector's ghost

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: What art thou that with such a grim aspect,
In this black night so dark and turbulent,
Haunts me in every corner of my house
Which yet burns o'er mine ears?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Dost thou not know me?
Or can Aeneas so forget his friend?
This face did fright Achilles in the field,
And when I shook these locks, now knotted all,
As baked in blood; all Greece hath quaked and trembled.
Look on mine heels, and thou mayst see those thongs
By which so often I was dragged about Troy,
My body made an universal wound
by the unnumbered hands of Myrmidons,
This th'hand that tossed so many wildfire balls
Into the Argive fleet, and this the body
That decked in Aiax and ac ills spoils
Rid from the fields triumphant thorough Troy.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Prince Hector?

sp.speaker: Hect.
sp.l: Hence Aeneas post from Troy,
Rear that abroad the gods at home destroy.
The city burns, Priam and Priam's glory
Is all expired, and tumbled headlong down:
Cassandra's long neglected prophecies
This night fulfils. If either strength or might
Could have protected Troy, this hand, this arms
That saved it oft, had kept it still from harm.
But Troy is doomed, here begins the fatal story
Of her sad sack and fall of all her glory.
Away, and bear thy country gods along,
Thousands shall issue from thy sacred seed,
Cities more rich than this the Grecian spoil,
In after times shall thy successors build,
Where Hector's name shall live eternally.
One Romulus, another bruit shall rear,
These shall nor honours, nor just rectors want,
Lombardy's room, great Britain's Troynovant.
Heu fuge nate dea, teque his pater eripe flammis;
Hostis habet muros, rvit alto a culmine Troia
Sacra, svosque tibi commendat Troia penates
Hos cape fatorum comites, his moenia quaere
Magna: pererrato statues quae denique ponto.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: Soft lie thy bones and sweetly may they rest
Thou wonder of all worthies, but Troy burns:
Thousands of Trojan corpse's block the streets,
Some flying fall, and some their killers kill:
Where shall I meet thee death? before I fly,
Some conquerors yet, shall bravely conquered die.

div.head: Acius secundus: scoena prima.
div.stage: Enter Priam in his nightgown and slippers, after him Hecuba, Helena, Andromache, Helena, Cassandra, Polyxena, Polites, Astyanax. An alarum.

sp.speaker: All la.
sp.l: O help us father Priam, o the Greeks.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: I have done more than age would suffer me
They have tilted masts against my palace gates,
And burst them open.

sp.speaker: All la.
sp.l: O father Priam, whether shall we fly?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: We are encompassed round with sword and fire,
Alas daughters, alas my young Astyanax.

sp.speaker: All la.
sp.l: O heaven, they come, where may we hide us safe?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Safety and help are both fled out of Troy,
And left behind nothing but massacre:
My palace is surprised my guard all slain,
Myself am wounded, but more with your shrieks,
Then by the swords of Grecians: come let's fly.
Unto the sacred altar of the gods.

sp.speaker: All la.
sp.l: May we be safe there father?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Safe? O no;
Safety is fled. Death hath our lives in chase,
And since we needs must die, let's choose this place.

div.stage: Alarum. Enter at the one door Hellen, at the other Cresida.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Whither runs Helen?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Whither should I fly?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: See, Troy is not itself, o wretched Helen!
To shun the Greeks to run into the fire,
Or flying fire, perish by Greekish steel:
Which hadst thou rather choose?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Death, in what shape soever he appears
To me is welcome, I'll no longer shun him;
but here with Cressida abide him: here,
O, why was Helen at the first so fair,
To be come subject to so foul an end?
Or how hath Cressida's beauty sinned 'gainst heaven,
That it is branded thus with leprosy?

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: I in conceit thought that I might contend
Against heaven's splendour, I did once suppose,
There was no beauty but in Cressida's looks,
But in her eyes no pure divinity:
But now behold me Helen.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: In her I see
All beauty's frailty, and this object makes
All fairness to show ugly in itself:
But to see breathless virgins piled on heap,
What less can Helen do then curse these stars
That shined so bright at her nativity,
And with her nails tear out these shining balls
That have set Troy on fire?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Pierce all the Trojan ladies with your swords,
Lest 'mongst them you might spare Polixena.

sp.speaker: Agam.
sp.l: Stay, I should know that face, 'tis Helena?

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: My Queen?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: I am not Helen, but Polixena:
Therefore revengeful Neoptolemus
Do justice on me for thy father's death.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Polixena? by all Achilles honours
I'll part thee limb from limb.

sp.speaker: Cres.
sp.l: Pyrrhus forbear,
It's the Spartan Queen.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: If Helen, the adulterous strumpet dies,
I'll be her deathsman.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Strike home Menelaus,
Death from thy hand is welcome.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Hold I say,
She's Clytaemnestra's sister, for her sake
Helen shall live, and kingly Menelaus
Receive her into favour.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Agamemnon
Is too remiss, I have sworn all blood to spill
I meet with, and this one will Pyrrhus kill.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: And I this other.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: For our sake Menelaus let her live.
Was not our sister born against her will
From Sparta? for that wrong done by the Trojans
Doth not Troy burn? and are not all our swords
Stained in the blood of Paris slaughtered friends?
You shall be reconciled to Helen,
And bear her back to Greece.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Helen at shrift ▪ alas poor penitent quean,
Dost hear me Menelaus? pardon her,
Take her again to Sparta, thou'lt else want
So kind a bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Take back my shame?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Yes for thy pleasure.
There's in the world as rich and honourable
As thou, who lend the pleasures of their bed
To others, and then take them back again
As they can get them.

sp.speaker: Men,
sp.l: My brow shall never bear
Such characters of shame.

sp.speaker: Ther,
sp.l: Thy brows bears horns already, but who sees them?
When thou returnest to Sparta, some will think
Thou art a cuckold, but who is't dare say so?
Thou art a King, thy sins are clouded o'er,
Where poor men's faults by tongues are made much more.
Of all men living, Kings are last shall hear
Of their dishonours.

sp.speaker: Aga
sp.l: What inferior beast
Dares tell the lion of his tyranny,
Who is not torn asunder with his paws?
The King of Sparta therefore needs not fear
the tongues of subjects bid our sister rise
To safety in thine arms.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Do Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: But will my Helen then by future virtue
Redeem her long lost honour?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: If with tears
The heavens may be appeased for Helen's sins,
They shall have penitent showers: if Menelaus
May with the spirit of love be satisfied,
He ten times rectify my forfeited honour
Before I touch his bed.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Arise then Helen, Menelaus' arms
Thus welcome thee to safety.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha,
Why this is well, for he that's born to die
A branded cuckold, hugs his destiny:
Go, get you after Pyrrhus to the slaughter,
I'll look to Helen.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Convey her to our guard.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Helen, hereafter see thou provest more wise,
If not more honest, yet be more precise,

div.stage: Enter prince Chorebus with other Trojans in Greekish habits.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: These shapes thrive well, we have guilt our Greekish arm●
With blood of their own nation ▪ some we have sent
To everlasting darkness, some repulsed
Back to their ships: some we have made to fly
Into their horse's bulk, whence Pyrrhus first
Leapt down upon his spear.

div.stage: Enter Synon, Thersites, and the Greeks dragging in Cassandra.

sp.speaker: Syn,
sp.l: Come soldiers, this is stately tragical,
The Greeks wade up even to the brawny thighs
In lukewarm blood of our despoiled foes.
Above Melpomene's huge buskined top
We plunge at every step, and bravely fought
By Troy's bright burning flame: that's now our light.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: More of our valiant mates, let's join with them,
This street yet's unassaulted and unfired:
Some balls of wildfire straight, and hurl this lady
Into the fury of the burning flame.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: My wife Cassandra?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Courage, let none scape
Fire, vengeance, blood, death, murder, spoil and rape.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: All these on Greece and twenty thousand more,
Till they like Troy be drowned in tears and gore.

div.stage: Chorebus and therest beat off the Greeks, and rescue Cassandra.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: From Greeks to Greeks, from fire kept for the sword, from one death to another.

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Cassandra no.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: My lord the prince Chorebus?

sp.speaker: Cho.
sp.l: Yes the same,
Who hath preserved thee both from sword and flame.

div.stage: Enter Aeneas with his father, who taking Chorebus for a Grecian by reason of his habit, fights with him and kills him.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: More Greeks and see Cassandra captive made,
Assault them Troians, rescue the fair Princess;
This way dear father mount my back again.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: O false Aeneas, thou hast slain thy friend:
Many a Greek (Thus shaped) he sent to hell,
And being a Trojan by a Trojan fell.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: He died not by my hand, but his own fate.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: And I forgive thee good Aeneas, fly,
Thou shalt survive, but Troy and we must fall:
The hope of all our future memories
Are stored in thee, take up thy sacred load
reverent Anchises bedrid through his age,
We are all doomed, fair Troy must perish here,
But thou art born a greater Troy to rear.

sp.speaker: Aene.
sp.l: The heavens have hand in all things, to their pleasure
We must subscribe: Creusa, where's my wife?
In losing her I save but half my life.
Come reverent father, on my shoulders mount,
Though thousand dangers dog us at the heels,
Yet will we force our passage.

div.stage: King Priam discovered kneeling at the altar, with him Hecuba, Polixena, Andromache, Aftianax: to them enter Pyrhus, and all the Greeks, Pyrhus killing Polytes Priam's son before the altar.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Still let your voices to high heaven aspire
For Pyrrhus' vengeance, murdering steel and fire.

sp.speaker: All the ladies.
sp.l: O, o.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: My son Polites? o thou more hard hearted
Then fatal Pyrrhus or his father's guard,
That in the shadow of this sacred place
Durst sprink the child's blood in the father's face.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Priam? thanks sweet revenge, through swords and armour,
Through mures, and countermures of men and steel;
Through many a corner, and blind entries mouth
I have followed this thy bleeding son to death,
Whose swift pursuit hath trained me to this altar
To be revenged on thee for the sad fate
Of great Achilles.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Thou art Pyrrhus then?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: My acts shall speak my name,
I am that Pyrrhus who did mount you horse
Hiding mine armour in his deep vast bulk,
The first that leapt out of his spacious side,
And tossed consuming fire in every street,
Which climbed, as if it meant to meet the stars,
I am that Pyrrhus before whom Troy falls:
before whom all the vanes and pinnacles
Bend their high tops, and from the battlements
On which they stand, break their aspiring necks.
The proudest roof and most imperious spire
Hath veiled to us and our all wasting fire.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Pyrrhus, I know thee for my destined plague,
I know the gods have left us to our weakness,
I see our glories ended and extinct,
And I stand ready to abide their doom;
Only for pity and for piety's sake
Be gracious to these ladies.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Pyrrhus no,
Such grace as they did to Achilles' show,
Let them all taste; let grace be far exiled,
Kill from the elder to the sucking child.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: He's prone enough to mischief of himself,
Spur not that fury on which runs too fast,
Nor add thou to old Priam's misery
Which scarce can be augmented 'tis so great.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Die in thy tortures then.

sp.speaker: Hecu.
sp.l: O spare his life.

sp.speaker: Asti
sp.l: Good man kill not my grandsire.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Good man do.

sp.speaker: Hecu.
sp.l: Kill me for him.

sp.speaker: Asti.
sp.l: No, she's my grandam too,
Indeed she's a good woman, choose some other
If you must needs kill.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: This then.

sp.speaker: Asti.
sp.l: She's my mother, you shall not hurt her.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: This boy had a father,
Hector his name, who had he lived to see
A sword bent 'gainst his wife, this Queen, or me,
He would have made all Greece as hot to hold him
As burning Troy is now to shelter us.

sp.speaker: Asti.
sp.l: Good grandsire weep not, grandam, mother, aunt
Alas, what mean you? If you be good men
Put up your swords and help to quench these flames,
or if in killing you such pleasure have,
Practice on him, kill that ill favoured knave.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Me brat?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Ulysses, Agamemnon. Menelaus,
Sinon, Thersites, and you valiant Greeks;
Behold the vengeance wrathful Pyrrhus takes
On Priam's body for Achilles' death:
Sinon, take thou that Siren Polyxene,
And hew her piecemeal on my father's tomb.
Thersites, make the womb of fifty princes
A royal sheath for thy victorious blade:
Diomed, let Cassandra die by thee,
And Agamemnon kill Andromache:
And as my sword through Priam's bulk shall fly,
Let them in death consort him, and so die.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: When, when, for Jove's sake when?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Some expeditious fate this motion further,
Methinks 'tis long since that I did a murder.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: O heaven, o Jove, stars, planets, fortune, fate,
To think what I have been, and what am now;
Father of fifty brave heroic sons,
But now no father, for they all are slain.
Queen Hecuba the mother of so many,
But now no mother: for her barren womb
Hath not one child to show, these fatal wars
Have eat up all our issue.

sp.speaker: Asti.
sp.l: My dear father,
And all my princely uncles.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: My dear husband,
And all my royal brothers.

sp.speaker: Hecu.
sp.l: Worthy Hector,
And all my valiant sons.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: And now that Priam that commanded Asia,
And sat enthroned above the Kings of Greece,
Whose dreaded navy scoured the Hellespont,
Sees the rich towers he built now burned to ashes:
The stately walls he reared, levelled and evened;
his treasures rifled and his people spoiled:
All that he hath on earth beneath the sun
Bereft him, saving his own life and these,
And my poor life with these, are (As you see)
Worse than the rest: they dead, we dying be.
Strike my stern foe, and prove in this my friend,
One blow my universal cares shall end.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: And that blow Pyrrhus strikes, at once strike all.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Why so, so, this was stately tragical.

div.stage: They are all slained at once.

sp.speaker: Asti.
sp.l: Where shall I hide me?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: So nimble Hector's bastard?
My father slew thy father, I the son:
Thus will I toss thy carcase up on high,
The brat above his father's fame shall fly.

div.stage: He tosseth him about his head and kills him.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: No, somewhat doth remain,
Alarum still, the people's not all slain,
Let not one soul survive.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Then trumpets sound
Till burning Troy in Trojan blood be drowned.

div.stage: The alarum continued, shreiks and clamours are heard within. Enter with drum, colours, and soldiers Agamemnon, Pyrhus, Ulysses, Diomed, Menelaus, Hellen, Thersites, Synon, etc.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: What more remains t'accomplish our revenge?
The proudest nation that great Asia nursed
Is now extinct in Lethe.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: All by Helen,
O had that tempting beauty never been born,
By whom so many worthies now lie dead.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: A hot pest take the strumpet.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: And a mischief.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: 'Twas this hot whore that set all Troy a fire.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Forgive me Pyrrhus for thy father's death,
Troy for thy sack, King Priam for thy sons,
Greece for an infinite slaughter, and you husband or all your nuptial wrongs, King Menelaus,
I must confess, my inconsiderate deed
Have made a world of valiant hearts to bleed.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: What, note is that which Pyrrhus' eye dwells on?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: The perfect number
Of Greeks and Trojans slain on either part.
The siege ten years, ten months, ten days endured,
In which there perished of the Greeks 'fore Troy
Eight hundred thousand and six thousand fighting men:
Of Trojans fell six hundred six and fifty thousand,
All soldiers; besides women, children, babes,
Whom this night massacred.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: All these I slew.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Nay, some this hand sent packing, that's not true.

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: Aeneas, with twenty two ships well furnished,
(The self same ships in which young Paris sailed
When he from Sparta stole fair Helena,)
Is fled to sea.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Antenor with five hundred Trojans more 'scaped through the gate called Dardan.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Let them go,
That of Troy's sack the world by them may know,
Where above thirty brave heroic Kings
Have breathed their last: besides inferior princes,
Barons and knights, eighteen imperial monarchs
With his own hands renowned Hector slew:
My father besides Troilus and that Hector,
Eight famous Kings that came in aid of Troy.
Three Trojan Paris with his arrows slew,
Of which one was my father: Diomed
Four monarchs with his bright sword sent to death.
Ourself the warlike Queen of Aemazons,
And aged Priam.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Bravely boast he can,
A wretched woman and a weak old man.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: And now Troy's wars are ended, we in peace
With glorious conquest to sail back to Greece.
Their nation's vanished like their city's smoke,
Our enemies are all ashes: worlds to come
Shall chronicle our pitiless revenge
In books of brass and leaves of adamant.
Towards Greece victorious leaders, our toil's past;
Troy and Troy's people we have burnt in flames,
And of them both left nothing but their names.

div.head: Actus quartus: scoena prima.
div.stage: Enter prince Cethus the son of King Naulus, and brother to Palamides.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: With wondrous joy they say, the Greeks return
With triumphs and ovations piercing heaven,
Where'er they set but foot loud paeans sung,
And odes to sphere-like notes tuned in their praise:
Whilst Cethus like a forlorn shadow walks
Despised, disgraced, neglected and debauched;
Playing his melancholy, cares and sorrows
On his discordant heartstrings. O my fate!
Shall I, that have this body and this brain,
A royalty stamped on me in my birth:
Whose wrongs have been of mark through all the world
Troubling each ear, and being disputable
By every tongue that hath been taught to speak,
Even in the mouths of babes, all rating me
Of cowardice and sloth: sleep, an occasion
Being fairly offered? No, awake revenge,
I'll bring the now to action.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Hear you the news

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Orestes friend, the noble Pylades?
Instruct mine ignorance, I know of none.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: This day the prince, great Agamemnon's heir●
Orestes whom you truly call your friend,
Betrothes the young and fair Hermione
Daughter to beauteous Helen.

sp.speaker: Ceth
sp.l: Hymen's joys.
Crown them with all true pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Shall we have your presence at the contract?

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Who's within?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Only Aegisthus, Clytaemnestra's friend,
The Queen and fair Electra.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Witness enough,
Then spare me for this time good Pylades,
We'll owe them greater service.

sp.speaker: Pyl.
sp.l: But 'tis a duty that I owe my friend,
My absence would distaste him.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Fare you well.
Do, do, contract and marry, aim at heaven,
But hell is that they plunge in: o Palamedes
My basely betrayed brother, sold at Troy
As we would cheapen horses, yet a prince:
A prince? nay general of the Greekish host.
Emperor and keyser, chose to that command
By a full jury of Kings, and by them rated
The prime and worthiest: who being far from equal
Could find in whole Greece no competitor.
Yet this peculiar man, this god of men,
By false Ulysses and Atreus sons
Agamemnon and Menelaus, basely supplanted;
Who, for they would confer amongst themselves
The sovereignty forged letters sent from Troy,
And coin withal marked with King Priam's stamp,
As if this father of his fame and nation
Whose only ends were aimed to honour Greece
Would have betrayed his people: this suggested,
My brother was arraigned, convict, condemned ;
for which I have vowed the universal ruin
Of all the Kings of that corrupted bench.
Palamedes thy blood in Asia shed
Shall make all Europe mourn since thou art dead.

div.stage: Enter Egistus, Clitemnestra, Orestes, Pilades, Hermione, and Electra.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Mycenae's King and Sparta's would be proud
To see this happy and blessed union made
Between their royal families.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: This fair virgin,
Second from Leda to whom Jove vouchsafed
The strict embrace of his immortal arm,
Unspotted with her mother's prostitution,
We'll thus receive.

sp.speaker: Hermi.
sp.l: May my chaste innocence
Break through the cloud which hath eclipsed her fame ▪
Whose luster may outshine my mother's frailties,
And they through me may be forgotten in Greece.

sp.speaker: Egi.
sp.l: Hermione, your words taste of your breeding
Under this Queen your fair and princely aunt,
Were young Electra but so well bestowed,
Great Agamemnon in so brave a match
Would think himself more graced, then in fruition
Of all the foreign trophies.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: May she prove?
A whore like to her mother: prince Orestes,
And you bright lady Spartans second light,
May all the virtues of this potent Queen
Take life in you, to prove hereditary
That the great archduke crowned with fame and honour.
In his return may add a surplusage
To his already surfeit: find his bed
By this adultress basely strumpeted,
And make the down they lie on quaff their blood.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: How do you fair Electra in your judgement
Applaud your brother's choice?

sp.speaker: Elect.
sp.l: As of a contract.
Made by the gods above, and now by princes
Here ratified on earth.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: I would my friend
Were to you sister, but as fast betrothed
As I to Helen's daughter: but dear Pylades,
'Tis time must perfect all things.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Madam you hear ▪
This motion from your brother.

sp.speaker: Elect.
sp.l: And I crave
Time to consider on't.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: 'Tis on foot,
Pursue it then with all advantages,
Command my free assistance to begin ▪
Had you Electra friend, as I Hermione;
We were at first as foreign as you two,
And every way as strange, but opportunity
That hath united us, may make you one.
After some amorous parlance, let us now
Unto the temple and there sacrifice
Unto the gods, that Greece ▪ no more may mourn●
But glory in our father's safe return ▪

sp.speaker: Egist,
sp.l: His safety is our danger ▪ for know madam ▪
Our love hath been too public.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: That's the ground
On which to build my project.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Grant it hath.
Cannot a more than nine years widowhood
Excuse me being a woman? thinks the King
We can forget that lesson in our age,
Which was by him first taught us in our youth?
Or was't his aim to show us choice delights,
Then bar us their fruition? First to taste
Our palate, next to make us appetite;
And when our stomachs are prepared and sharpened
For costly viands placed before our eyes,
Then to remove the table? he's unkind;
and as he hath dealt with us, so must find.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: The Queen? to her my speed is.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Speak on soldier.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: I am the herald of most happy news,
Troy with the earth is levelled, sacked, and burned;
Priam with all his memory extinct,
Queen, daughters, sons, and subjects ruined all.
Now like the vapour of their city's smoke,
And of them no more found: and madam now
The King your lord, the elder of the Atryd's,
Duke of the puissant and all conquering host,
His temples arched in a victorious orb,
And wreathed in all the glories earth can yield
Is landed in Mycene a conqueror .

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: How could they scape those fierce fires naulus made
In vengeance of his son Palamedes
To split their cursed fleet upon the rocks.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Make repetition of their joys again,
Being things that I cannot hear too oft ▪
And add to them: is Menelaus safe
My husband's brother? Helen how fares she?
Or is she thence repurchased? fill mine ears
With such sweet tones, 'tis all I can desire.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Take your full longing then, for though the seas
With tempests, storms, rocks, shipwracks, shelves and sands
More damaged them then all the Trojan siege.
Although the beacons fired to draw their fleet
Distressed and dispersed upon the rocks
Sunk many a goodly bottom: yet the general
'Scaped by the hand of Jove, with him King Diomed,
Ulysses, and great Neoptolemus,
With Spartan Menelaus late attend
With beauteous Helen cause of all these broils:
All these attend upon the general
To bring him home victorious, and this night
Will lodge in the King's palace,

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Soldier thanks,
These twice five years I have a widow been,
Thy news have now new married me: give order
For the King's entertainment, all the state
Mycene can yield shall freely be exposed
In honour of these princes: your great haste
Doth ask some rest, therefore repose yourself,
And for your fortunate news expect reward.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: The Queen is royal.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: And now to that devil
Which I must conjure up: is the Queen mad?
Or thou Aegisthus sottish? see you not
The stake and scaffold, nay the hangman too;
And will you blindfold run upon your deaths
When there is way to 'scape them?

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: What horrid fright
Is this proposed by Cethus?

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: The king's returned,
And doth not your veins gush out of your temples
In sanguine blushes? are not your adulteries
Famous as Helen's? nay, more infamous,
There was a rape to countenance what she did,
You naught save corrupt lust and idleness:
'Tis blabbed in the city, talked on in the court,
All tongues surcharged, all eyes are fixed on you,
To see what fearful vengeance he will take
For that your prostitution.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: He's a King.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: True Clytaemnestra, so he went from hence,
But is returned a tyrant fleshed in blood:
Thinkest thou that he who quelled his foes abroad,
Will spare at home domestic enemies?
That was so prone to punish others wrongs,
And can forget his own?

sp.speaker: Cli,
sp.l: If Menelaus
Have pardoned Helen, may not he his brother
Make Sparta's King his noble precedent,
to do the like to me?

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Tush shallow Queen,
How you mistake; see imminent fate affront you,
And will not shun it coming? If his brother
Be branded as a scandal to the world,
What consequence is it that he will groan
Under the self same burden? rather think
He hath proposed a vengeance dire and horrid
To terrify, not countenance such misdeeds:
And this must fall on you, lest time to come
Should chronicle his family for a brood
Of cuckolds and of strumpets:

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: This thy language
Strikes me with horror.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: And affrights me too.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Is he not King? hath he not lynx's eyes,
And giant's arms, the first to see far off,
The last as far to punish? was he so poor
In friends at home, to leave no Argus here
To keep his eyes still waking? think it not
But that he knew the treason of his bed,
He had not fair Briseis snatched perforce
From th'arms of great Achilles.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: That I heard.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Why hath he a new mistress brought from Troy,
But to state her in Clytaemnestra's stead,
And make her Mycenae's Queen whilst you poor wretches
Like malefactors suffer, marked for the stag
And most ridiculous spectacles.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: You show the danger,
But teach us no prevention ▪

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: See before us
The objects of our fears and difficulties,
But not the way to avoid them.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Hear me then,
Prevent your death's by his.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: How? kill the King?
So we heap sin on sin and basely add
Unto adultery murder.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Per scelus semper tutum sceleribus iter .
Boldly you have begun, and being once in,
Blood will cure lust, and mischief physic sin.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Perhaps our guilt lies hid.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: In a King's palace
Can lust in such great persons be concealed?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: The first offence repents me, and to that
I should but add a greater.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Perish, do.
Or what concerns this me? I shall be safe,
I have strumpeted no Agamemnon's Queen,
Nor bastarded the issue of the Atrides:
Or why should I thus labour their securities
Who study not their own?

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Resolve then Queen,
The Kings austere, and will extend his justice
Unto some sad example.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: O but my husband.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: After ten years widowhood
Can Clytaemnestra think of such a name?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: You have half won me, when shall this be done?

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: When but this night? delays are ominous:
Ere he have time to think upon his wrongs,
Or find a tongue to whisper, ere suspicion
Can further be instructed or least censure,
To call his wrongs in question: instantly,
Even in his height of joy, fullness of compliment
With th' Argive Kings: whilst cups are brimmed with healths,
Whilst jealousies are drowned in Bacchus' boles.
This night before he sleep, or that his pillow
Can give him the least counsel, ere he can spare
A minute for the smallest intelligence,
Or moment to consider: I have done
If you have either grace in apprehension
Or spirit in performance.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: I have both,
What answers Clytaemnestra?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: I am swayed,
And though I know there's difference of justice
In princes sitting on the scarlet bench,
And husbands dallying in the private bed:
I'll hold him as one sits upon my life,
Not one that lies enclosed within mine arms;
He's now my judge, not husband, here I vow
Assistance in his death.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: And so survive
Secure and fortunate.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: This night?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: The project I have cast with all security.
And safety for your person: smooth your brows,
And let there shine a welcome in your looks
At the King's entertainment: nay begone,
By this time you are expected; what remains
Is mine in form, but yours in action.
Now father style me a most worthy son
Palamedes, a brother, what neither fires,
Nor rocks could do, what neither Neptune's rage,
Nor Mars his fury, what the turbulent seas,
Nor the combustious land ▪ that Cethus can:
He that succeeds my brother in his rule,
Shall first succeed in death: none that had hand
Or voice in his subversion that shall stand.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Well met on land kind brother, we are now
Victorious: let's be proud on't.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Thou say'st true,
We are conquerors in our basest cowardice,
We had not been here else.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Valiant Hector,
Achilles, Troilus, Paris, Aiax too.
They are all fallen, we stand.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Yes, and will stiff
When all the Grecian princes that survive
Are cramped and ham-stringed.

sp.speaker: Ther.
