sp.l: Wast thou not sea-sick brother?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Horribly, and feared
In the rough seas to have disgorged my heart,
And there to have fed haddocks.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Trojans were fellows
In all their fury to be parleyed with:
But with the tempests, gusts, and furicanes,
The warring winds, the billows, rocks and fires
There was no talking: these few times we prayed,
The gods would hear no reason.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: 'Twas because
The billows with their roaring, and the winds
Did with their. whistling keep them from their ears:
But now all's hushed, could we find time to pray,
They might find time to hear us.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Shall we be
Spectators of the royal interview
Betwixt the King and Queen?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Ten years divorced
Should challenge a kind meeting, let's observe
The form and state of this court-complement,
(Things I did never trade with:) hark loud music
Gives warning of their coming.

div.stage: Loud music. Enter at one door Agamemnon, Ulysses, Diomed, Pyrhus, Menelaus: Synon and Thersites falling into their train. At the other Egistus, Clitemnestra, Cethus, Orestes, Pylades, Hermione, Electra, etc.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Unto our country and our household-gods
We are at length returned, trophied with honours,
With Troy's subversion and rich Asia's spoils,
This is a sacred day.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Such Troy had once.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Unto the gods we'll sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: So Priam fell
Before the holy altar.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: This city is not Troy.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Where Helen treads,
I hold the place no better.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: See our Queen,
Orestes and Electra, for our sake.
Princes of Greece deign them your best salutes ▪
Dear Clytaemnestra.

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: Royal King and husband.

div.stage: After their salute. All the rest compliment as strangers, but especially Pyrhus and Orestes ▪

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: What's he that kneels so close unto our Queen

sp.speaker: Clit.
sp.l: Aegisthus and your servant.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: He was young
When we at first set sail from Aulis gulf,
Now grown from my remembrance: we shall ●●ude
Fit time to search him further,

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Mark you that.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Yes, and it touched me deeply.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Our sister, and this young Hermione,
Daughter to us and Helen.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Pretty puppy.
Of such a common brach.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Young Neoptolemus,
This is the lady promised you at Troy,
For your great service done there: she's your own,
Freely embrace her then.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: I see we are like
To have a jolly kindred.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Pyrrhus, enjoy
Her whom I have in contract?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Beauteous lady,
The greatest ambition Pyrrhus aims at now,
Is how to know you farther.
Hath been so mighty to revenge the wrongs
Of my fair mother, can from Hermione
Challenge no less than welcome.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: O you gods,
Pyrrhus, thou wert more safe in burning Troy
With horror, fury blood, fires, foes about them.
Then in my father's court.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Another column
On which to build my slaughters. Patience prince,
This is no time for braves and menaces,
I further shall instruct you.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: I have done.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: See now the two Queens meet, and smack in public,
That oft have kissed in corners ▪

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Thersites?
Thou art grown a monster, a strange thing scarce known
'Mongst soldiers, wives and daughters.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: They are two sisters.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Yes, and the two king-brothers royally
Between them two cornuted ▪

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: We are too loud.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Princes of Greece, since we have done a duty
To see our general midst his people safe,
And after many dreadful wars abroad
In peace at home. 'tis fit we should disperse
Unto our several countries instantly,
I purpose for Aetolia, where my Queen
With longing waits my coming.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Not King Diomed,
Till you have seen Mecena's pomp and state
In ampliest royalty expressed at full,
Both tasted of our feasts and princely gifts.
The fair Aegiale, who hath so long
Forborned your presence, will not I presume
Deny to spare you to us some few days,
To add to the year's number, though not as general
Yet will I lay on you a friend's command ▪
which must not be denied.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Great Agamemnon
With me was ever powerful, I am his.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: And now fair sister welcome back from Troy,
Be ever henceforth Sparta's.

sp.speaker: Hei.
sp.l: Your great care
In my enforced absence (Gracious Queen)
Expressed unto my dear Hermione,
Hath much obliged me to you. O my fate,
How swift time runs: Orestes grown a man,
Whom I left in the cradle! Young Electra
Then (As I take't) scarce born, and now grown ripe,
Even ready for an husband!

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: In whose absence
If but one handsome sweetheart come in place,
She'll not turn tail for't, if she do but take
After mine old naunt Helen.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The great and solemn preparation
Of the court, state and glory mighty princes,
Attend for you within.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: All are consecrated
Unto your royal welcomes, enter then,
We'll feast like earthy gods, or godlike men ▪

div.stage: Lo●d music. They possess the stage in all state, Cathus stayeth behind.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: My brain about again, for thou hast found
New project now to work on, and 'tis here,
Orestes hath received Hermione
From Clitemnestra's hand, her soul is his ▪
And he her genius, two combined in one:
Yet she is by the father's oath conferred
On Pyrrhus, which shall breed a stormy flaw
Never to be pieced again, but by the deaths
Of the two hopeful youths: perhaps the hazard
Of all these Kings if my revenge strike home.
(Of that at leisure) but the bloody stage
On which to act, general this night is thine,
Thou liest down mortal, who must rise divine.

div.stage: Enter Orestes to Cethus. Music and healthing within.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: O Cethus what's this music unto me,
That are composed of discords? what are healths
To him that is struck heartsick? all those joys
Whose leaders seem to pierce against the roofs
Of these high structures, to him that is struck down
Half way below the centre?

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Were you lower,
Yet here's a hand can raise you, deeper cast
Then to the lowest abysm: it lies in me
To advance you to the height of happiness,
Where you shall live eterniled from the reach
Of any humane malice.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Hadst thou seen
Her, in whose breast my heart was paradised,
Kissed, courted, and embraced.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: By Pyrrhus.

sp.speaker: Orest ▪
sp.l: Him:
What passionate and insidiating looks
He cast on her, as if in scorn of me:
Shall he enjoy my birthright, or inherit
Where I am heir apparent? shall he usurp ▪
Or plead my interest, where I am possessed?
Rule where I reign? where I am stated, sit?
Brave me in my peculiar sovereignty?

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: He must not, shall not.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Show me to depose.
The proud usurper then.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Prince, make't my charge.
In the mean time, from your distracted from
Exile all discontent, let not lest rage
Reign in your eye, or harshness in your tongue,
Smooth waters are still deep'st ▪ wait on the King,
and be no stranger to your mother's eye,
Or foreign to your kindred: the feast spent,
And night with it: the morrow shall beget
Project of more import (Scarce thought on now.)

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: I build upon thy counsel.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Which hath proved,
Fixed as a rock, still constant, and unmoved.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: What Cethus here? why no such matter now
No cause of fear, or least suspicion.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Your reason?

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Tush, presume it, we are safe.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Observe it, they are still securest, whom
The devil drives to ruin.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Hark, their healths
Carousing to the general's victories,
In all thy heat of joy, and fire of wine,
No spark of jealously, all th' argument
Of their discourse, what they have done at Troy.
Still health on health, and the great general
So far from seeming to have least distaste,
That in all affable terms he courts his Queen,
Nay more, cuts off all banquet ceremonies,
To hasten his bed-pleasures, as if times distance
Betwixt his board and pallet, seemed more tedious
Than all his ten years siege.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Go, lost man,
Sink on firm ground, be shipwrecked in a calm.
These healths are to your ruins, his revenge:
Hath not Aegisthus read of a disease
Where men die laughing: others that have drunk
Poison instead of cordials, perish so?
To die 'tis nothing, since 'tis all men due:
But wretchedly to suffer, fall unpitied,
Unpitied? nay derided, mocked, and cursed:
To die as a base traitor, and a thief,
The adulterator of his sovereign's bed,
the poison of the Atredas family,
And scandal of his issue, so to die?

sp.speaker: Egi.
sp.l: Aegisthus will prevent, he by this hand
Must fall, 'fore whom all Asia could not stand.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: The banquet is broke up, sleep calls to rest,
And midnight's hour for murder, still shows best ▪

div.stage: Loud music. Enter Egistus with his sword drawn, hideth himself in the chamber behind the bed-curtaines: all the Kings come next in, conducting the general and his Queen to their lodging, and after some compliment leave them, enery one with torches ushered to their several chambers, etc.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Methinks this night, we Clytaemnestra meet,
At a new bridal; all attendants leave us,
We now are only for bed-privacies.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Great sir, I that so long have been your widow,
Will be this night your handmaid.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: You told me, Queen,
Orestes was a cunning horseman grown:
It pleased me much to hear it.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Greece reports
No centare can ride better ▪

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: And young Electra,
In all th' endowments that may best become
A Princess of her breeding, most complete.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: It was in your long absence, all my care,
(Being my charge) that you at your return
Might find them to your wishes,

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Thanks for that.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: How cunningly he seems to carry it ▪
But we must find prevention.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Who's without there?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Why started you?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Not all the Asian legions, no not Hector
Armed with his balls of wildfire, had the power
To shake me like this tremor: is our palace
less safe in Greece, amid our subjects here,
Then were our tents in Asia?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Where, if not here in Clytaemnestra's arms,
Can safety dwell?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: And fair Queen, it should be so.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: But why sir cast you such suspicious eyes
About your chamber? are we not alone?
Or will you to the private sweets of night,
Call tell tale witness?

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Now 'tis gone again. Shall we to rest?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: So please you royal sir.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: How hard this down feels, like a monument
Cut out of marble. Beds resemble graves,
And these methinks appear like winding sheets,
Prepared for corpses.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: O how ominously
Do you presage: you much affright me sir
In this our long-wished meeting.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: All's shook off.
I now am armed for pleasure: you commended
Late one Aegisthus to me, prithee Queen
Of what condition is he?

div.stage: They both wound him, at which there is a great thunder crack.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Tyrant this.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: And I am thus his second.

sp.speaker: Aga.
sp.l: Treason, murder, treason:
This shows, we princes are no more than men.
Thanks Jove 'tis fit when monarchs fall by treason,
Thunder to all the world, would show some reason.

sp.speaker: Egi.
sp.l: The deed is done, let's fly to some strong citadel,
For our more safety.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: He thus made divine:
Now my Aegisthus, I am solely thine.

div.stage: Anoyse of uproar within. Enter all the Kings with other servants half unready, as newly started from their beds. Orestes, Hermione, Pillades, Electra, etc.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: What strange tumultuous noise is this so late ▪
To rouse us from our beds?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Prodigious sure,
Since 'tis confirmed by thunder.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: In mine ears
Did never sound seem half too terrible.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Nor to your eyes, as this sad object is,
See great Atrides grovelling.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: What damned villain
Was author of this project?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Horrid sight.

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Rest you amazed all, as thunder struck,
And without sense or motion apoplexed,
And only hear me speak: Orestes, he
Who as if marbled by Medusa's head,
Hath not one tear to fall, or sigh to spend,
Till I find out the murderer, and on him
Inflict remarkable vengeance: for I vow
Were it my father, brother, or his Queen,
Hadst thou my weeping sister hand in it.
If he? whom equal, (If not ranked above)
I ever did, and shall love Pylades?
Wert she whose womb did bear me, where I lay
Full nine months bedded ere I saw the sun,
Or the most abject traitor under heaven,
Their dooms were all alike, and this I vow.
Now you whom this silent and speechless King
Hath oft commanded, this now senseless brain
As oft directed, this now strengthless hand
More oft protected in a war, that shall
Be to all times example: lend your shoulders
To bear him, who hath kept you all in life,
This is a black and mourning funeral right,
Deeds of this nature must be thoroughly searched,
Nay be revenged: the gods have said 'tis good,
The morning sun shall rise and blush in blood.

div.stage: They bear him off with a sad and funeral march, etc.

div.head: Actus quintus: scoena prima.
div.stage: Enter Pyrhus, Hermione, Thersites, and Synon.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Sweet lady, can you love:

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Forbear my lord,
Can such a thing as love be once named here,
Where every marble that supports this roof,
In emulation doth vie tears with us?
Nay where the wounds of such a mighty King
Have yet scarce bled their last.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Tush fair Hermione,
These sights that seem to ladies terrible,
Are common to us soldiers; when from field returning
All smeared in blood, where Dukes and Kings lie slain,
Yet in our tents at midnight it frights not us
From courting a sweet mistress.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: He say right,
And note of this how I can poetize:
This his great father of his love desired.
When from the slaughter of his foes retired
He doffed his cushes and unarmed his head,
To tumble with her on a soft day bed:
It did rejoice Brifois to embrace
His bruised arms, and kiss his bloodstained face.
These hands which he so often did imbrue
In blood of warlike Trojans whom he slew,
Were then employed to tickle, touch and feel,
And shake a lance that had no print of steel.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Continue in that vein, I'll feed thy muse
With crayfish, prawns and lobsters.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: You brought these of purpose to abuse me.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Peace Thersites,
And Sinon you no more.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: We see by Agamemnon all are mortal,
And I but show his niece Hermione
The way of all flesh.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: 'Tis an easy path,
(The mother and the aunt have trod it both)
If she have wit to follow.

div.stage: Enter Ulysses, Menelaus, Diomed with others.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: If it be so, Aegisthus is a traitor,
And she no more our sister.

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: 'Tis not possible
A Queen of her high birth and parentage
Should have such base hand in her husband's death,
Her husband and her sovereign.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Double treason,
Could it be proved against her.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: It appears
So far against humanity and nature
We dare not once suspect it, but till proof
Explain it further, hold it in suspense.

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: O but their sudden flight and fortifying.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: These are indeed presumptions, but leave that
To a most strict inquiry even for reverence
Of majesty and honour to all Queens,
For love of us because she was our sister,
Both for Orestes and Electra's sake
Whose births are branded in so foul a deed
Till we examine further circumstances
Spare your severer censures.

sp.speaker: Vlis.
sp.l: 'Tis a business
That least concerns us, but for honour's sake
And that he was our general.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: What, prince lie Pyrrhus courting our fair daughter?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Yes sir, but in a time unseasonable
Even as the suit itself is.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: All delays
Shall be cut off and she be swayed by us.
these royal princes ere they leave Mycena,
Shall see these nuptial rights solemnised,
We'll keep our faith with Pyrrhus.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: We our vows
As constant to the bright Hermione.
First see the royal general here interred
And buried like a soldier, 'tis his due:
To question of his death concerns not us,
We leave it to heaven's justice and revenge.
The rights performed with fair Hermione,
Then to our several countries each man post,
Captains disperse still when the general's lost.

div.stage: Enter Cethus, Orestes, and Pylades. disguised.

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Aegisthus? and our mother?

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Am I Cethus,
Are you Orestes, and this Pylades,
So sure they were his murderers: this disguise
Will suit an act of death, full to the life
He stands upon a strict and secure guard,
I have plotted your admittance, it will take
Doubt not, it cannot fail, I have cast it so.

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: As sent from Menelaus?

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Whose name else
Can break through such strong guards, where fear and guilt
Keep hourly watch?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: It is enough, I have't,
And thou the faithfullest of all friends dear Pylades,
Do but assist me in my vowed revenge
And enjoy fair Electra.

sp.speaker: Pyl.
sp.l: Next your friendship
It is the prize I aim at, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: What slip you time and opportunity,
Or look you after dreams?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: I am a wake.
And to send them to their eternal sleep.
In expedition there is still success,
in all delays defect: the traitor dies
Were he in league with all the destinies.
And 'tis a fruitful year for villainy,
And I a thriving farmer. In this interim
I have more plots on foot: King Menelaus:
I have incensed against proud Diamed ▪
Pyrrhus against Orestes, he 'gainst him,
Ulysses without parallel for wit
Against them all: so that the first combustion
Shall burn them up to ashes. O Palamedes,
So dear was both thy love and memory,
Not Helen by her whoredom caused more blood
Streaming from princes' breasts, than Cethus shall
(Brother) for thine untimely funeral.

div.stage: Enter Egistus, Clitemnestra with a strong guard.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Let none presume to dare into our presence
Or pass our guard, but such well known to us and to our Queen.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: The charge hath passed us round ▪

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: When sins of such high nature 'gainst us rise,
'Tis fit we should be kept with heedful eyes.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Presume it my Aegisthus, we are safe,
The fort wherein we live impregnable:
Or say we were surprised by stratagem,
Or should expose our lives unto the censure
Of law and justice, even in these extremes
There were not the least fear of difficulty.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Your reason madam.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Whom doth this concern
But our own blood? should Pyrrhus grow enraged ▪
I have at hand my niece Hermione
To calm his fury: what doth this belong to
Ulysses, or Aetolian Diomed?
Are they not strangers? If it come in question
By Menelaus, is he not our brother ▪
our sister Helen in his bosom sleeps,
And can with him do all things, fear not then,
We are every way secure.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: O but Orestes
His eye's to me like lightning, and his arm
Up heaved thus, shows like Jones thunderbolt
Aimed against lust and murder.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: He's our son,
The filial duty that's hereditary
Unto a mother's name prevents these fears:
Electra's young, and childish Pylades
Swayed by his friend: it rests, could we but work
Helen and Menelaus to our faction,
Aegisthus should be stated in Mycene,
We live his Queen and bride.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Fear's still suspicious.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: A letter sir.

sp.speaker: Egi.
sp.l: From whence?

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: 'Tis superscribed from the great Spartae's King,
And the Queen Helen.

sp.speaker: Egi.
sp.l: Who the messenger?

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Two gentlemen who much importune you
For speedy answer.

sp.speaker: Egi.
sp.l: Bid them wait without,
Now fates prove but propitious, than my kingdom
I shall presume established.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: There's no fear,
Orestes once removed, and that's my charge
Either by sword or poison.

sp.speaker: Egi.
sp.l: See fair Queen,
Read what your brother writes, by this we are
Eternised in our happiness, and our lives
Rooted in sweet security.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: We not suspect you in our brother's death,
A deed too base for any noble breast.
Therefore in this necessity of state,
And knowing in this forced vacancy
So great a kingdom cannot want a guide:
The sovereignty we thought good to confer
On Clytaemnestra, or what substitute
She in her best discretion shall think fit,
The united Kings of Greece have thus decreed.
Your brother Menelaus.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: We are happied ever.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: A joy ratified ▪
And subject to no change.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Call in the messengers,
Orestes and Electra once removed,
We have no rival, no competitor,
Therefore no jealousy at all.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: None, none.
The gods have with these Kings of Greece agreed
In his supplanting and instating thee,
Thee my most dear Aegisthus.

div.stage: Orestes and Pyllades disguised are conducted in.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: You the men?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Those, whom the Spartan King made special choice of
To trust this great affair with.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: And you're welcome,
But are you men of action: such I mean,
As have been soldiers bred, whose eyes enured
To slaughter and combustions: at the like
Would not change face, or tremble?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: They that to see
Legs, arms, and heads strowed on Scamander plain,
Kings by the common soldiers stewed in gore,
And three parts hid with their imboweld steeds,
Shadowing their mangled bodies from the sun,
as if above the earth to bury them:
They that to see an Asian potentate
Killed at the holy altar, his own blood
Mixed with his sons and daughters, tower's demolished
Crushing whole thousands, of each sex and age
Beneath their ruins: and these horrid sights
Lighted by scathe - fires, they that have beheld
These and more dreadful objects; can their eyes
Move at a private slaughter?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: You're for us,
Will you for hire, for favour, or advancement,
(Now wars are done) to be made great in court,
And undertake that one man easily spared
Amongst so many millions (Now surviving)
That such a creature, no way necessary
But a mere burden to the world we live in,
He might no longer live?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: But name the man,
And as I love Aegisthus, honour you
And all that glory in such noble deeds.
Be what he will; he's lost.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Orestes, then?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Is there none then the world so well may spare
As young Orestes? He to do't?

div.stage: He kills Egistus, first discovering himself.

sp.speaker: Egist.
sp.l: Vain world farewell,
My hopes withal, no building long hath stood
Whose sleight foundation hath been laid in blood.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: I'll die upon his bosom.

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Secure the fort my dear friend Pylades,
And to your utmost pacify the guard:
Tell them we are Orestes and their prince,
And what we did was to revenge the death
Of their dead lord and sovereign ▪

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Sir I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: O me, that thinking to have caught at heaven,
Am plunged into an hell of misery.
Aegisthus dead? what comfort can I have,
one foot enthroned, the tother in the grave.

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Can you find tears for such an abject groom,
That had not for an husband one to shed?
O monstrous, monstrous woman ▪ is this carrion,
Is this dead dog, (Dog said I?) nay what's worse,
Worthy the sigh or mourning of a Queen,
When a King lies unpitied?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Thou a son?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: The name I am ashamed of: o Agamemnon,
How sacred is thy name and memory!
Whose acts shall fill all foreign chronicles
With admiration, and most happy he
That can with greatest art but book thy deeds:
Yet whilst this rottenness, this gangrened flesh
Whose carcase is as odious as his name
Shall stinking lie, able to breed a pest,
He with a Princess tears to be embalmed,
And a King lie neglected?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Bastard.

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: If I be,
Damned be the whore my mother, ay, I am sure
Nor my dead father had no hand in it.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: O that I could but lengthen out my years
Only to spend in curses.

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Upon whom?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: On whom but thee for my Aegisthus' death?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: And I could wish myself a Nestor's age
To curse both him and thee for my dead father.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Dost thou accuse me for thy father's death?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Indeed 'twould ill become me being a son,
But were I sure it were so, than I durst;
Nay, more than that, revenge it.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Upon me?

sp.speaker: Ore.
sp.l: Were all the mothers of the earth in one,
All empresses and Queens cast in one mould,
And I unto that one a only son,
My sword should ravish that incestuous breast
of nature, and of state ▪

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: I am as innocent of that black deed,
As was this guiltless gentleman here dead.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: O all you powers of heaven I invocate,
And if you will not hear me, let hell do't:
Give me some sign from either fiends or angel,
I call you both as testates.
sp.stage: Enter the ghost of Agamemnon, pointing unto his wounds: and then to Egistus and the Queen, who were his murderers, which done, he vanisheth.
sp.l: Godlike shape,
Have you (My father) left the Elysium fields,
Where all the ancient hero's line in bliss,
To bring yourself that sacred testimony,
To crown my approbation: lady see.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: See what? thy former murder makes thee mad,

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Rest ghost in peace, I now am satisfied,
And need no further witness: saw you nothing?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: What should I see save this sad spectacle,
Which blood-shoots both mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: And nothing else?

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Mine eyes are clearer sighted then, and see
Into thy bosom. Murderess.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Incestuous strumpet, whose adulteries,
When treason could not hide, thou thoughts to cover,
With most inhumane murder.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Meaning us?

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Then, monster, thou didst first instruct mine hand,
How to write blood, when being a wife and Queen,
Thou killed'st a King and husband, and hast taught
Me being a son, how to destroy a mother.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: O most unnatural.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: That I learned of thee.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Unheard of cruelty, but heavens are just.
And all remarkable sins punish with mark,
One mischief still another doth beget,
Adultery murder: I am lost, undone.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Being no wife, Orestes is no son.

div.stage: Enter Cethus and Pillades with the guard.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: The guard all stand for you, acknowledging
Orestes prince and King.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: I now am neither.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: What object's this? Queen Clytaemnestra slain?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: I hope no son's hand in't

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Orestes did it,
The other title's lost.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: All my plots take
Beyond my apprehension.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: This is an age
Of nothing but portents and prodigies.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: The father's hand as deep was in her death
As was the sons, he pointed, and I struck:
Was he not then as unkind to a wife,
As I was to a mother?

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: O my friend,
What have you done?

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: There is a plasma, or deep pit
Just in the centre fixed for parricides,
I'll keep my court there, and Erinys, she
In stead of Hebe, shall attend my cup,
Charon the ferryman of hell shall be
My Ganymede.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: The prince is sure distracted.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: New project still for me.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: I'll have a guard of furies which shall light me
Unto my nuptial bed with funeral teades,
The fatal sisters shall my handmaidens be,
And wait upon the fair Hermione.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Hermione? she is betrothed to Pyrrhus,
And (Mourning for your absence) all the way
Unto the temple she will strow with tears.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Ha? Pyrrhus' rape my dear Hermione?
He that shall dare to interpose my purpose ▪
Or cross me in mine hymeneal rights,
I'll make him lie as flat on the cold earth
As doth this hound Aegisthus.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: And I would so.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Would? Nay I will, his father wore a smocks,
And in that shape raped Deiadamia.
He shall not use my love so, o my mother;
Friend take that object hence.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: But you Hermione,

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: My hand's yet deep in blood, but to the wrist,
It shall shall be to the elbow: gods, nor men,
Angels, nor furies shall my rage withstand,
Not the grave honour of th' assembled Kings,
Not reverence of the altar, nor the priest:
No superstition shall my fury slay ▪
Till Pyrrhus from the earth be swept away,

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Pylades attend your friend.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: He's all my charge,
My life and his are twins.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Their mines are countermined, Cethus, thy fall
Is either plotted, or to blow up all.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: My head aches brother.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: What a bachelor,
And troubled with the Spartan King's disease?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: No, there's a wedding breeding in my brain,
Pyrrhus the bridegroom: thou strange creature woman ▪
To what may I compare thee?

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Canst thou devise ought bad enough?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: 'Tis said they look like angels, and of light ▪
But for the most part, such light angels prove,
Ten hundred thousand of their honesties
Will scarce weigh eleven drachmas.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Clytaemnestra,
and Helen for example.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Young Hermione
Hath face from both.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: The sharp shrew's nose, they hate hereditary.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Thersites, I commend that fellow's wit
Proffered a wife young, beautiful and rich,
Only one fault she had, she wanted brain:
Who answered in a creature of that sex,
I ne'er desire more wisdom; then to know
Her husband's bed from another's.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: I commend him,
But 'tis not in th' Atrides family,
To find out such a woman.

div.stage: An altar set forth, enter Pyrhus lending Hermione as a bride, Menelaus, Ulysses, Diomed. a great train, Pyrhus and Hermione kneel at the altar.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: See now the sacred nuptial rights proceed ▪
The priests prepare the altar.

sp.speaker: Fyr.
sp.l: Hymen to whom my vows I consecrate
As all my love. To thee Hermione,
Whom in the presence of these Argive Kings,
I hear contract, be thou auspicious to us:
This flamming substitute to Saturn's son,
Within whose sacred temple we are roofed ▪
And before all these high celestial gods
And goddesses, in whose eyes now we kneel:
Especially you Juno Queen of marriage,
And fair Lucina, who have childbirths charge,
Your favours I invoke: let your chaste fires
Dry up this virgin's tears; make her so fruitful
That in her issue great Achilles' name
And fame withal, may live eternally ▪
Proceed priest to your other ceremonies ▪

div.stage: Enter Orestes, Cethes, and Pilades, with the guard, all their weapons drawn, Orestes 〈◊〉 at Pyrhus.

sp.speaker: Orest.
sp.l: Priam before the holy altar fell,
Before the altar bid thy life farewell:
Rescue Hermione.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Achilles son
Cannot revengeless die, then witness all,
Blood must flow high where such great princes fall.

sp.speaker: Pil.
sp.l: Orestes is in danger.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Save prince Pyrrhus.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: This plot was laid
Both for your life and kingdom.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Menelaus: shall never bear it so.

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: Fie Thersites,
Thy sword against me.

sp.speaker: Ther.
sp.l: Curse upon all whores.

div.stage: A confused scuffle, in which Orestes kills Pyrhus: Pyrhus, Orestes: Cethus wounds Pillades, Diomed, Menelaus, Ulysses, Thersites, etc. All fall dead sane Ulysses, who beareth thence Hermione: which done, Cethus riseth up from the dead bodies and speaks.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: What all asleep? and are these gossiping tongues,
That boasted naught save war and victory,
Now mute and silent? O thou ugly rogue,
Where's now thy railing? and thou parricide,
Thy madness is now tamed, thou needest no chains
To bring thee to thy wits, darkness hath don't.
This Diomed? who dared to encounter Mars,
And said to wound fair Venus in the hand:
Where's your valour now? Aegiale,
Unless (As some say) she be better stored,
Is like to lie without a bedfellow:
Rise Pylades, and help to awake thy friend,
What doth your friendship sleep now? Menelaus
Hellen's with a new sweetheart ith' next room,
Wilt thou be still a cuckold? wink at errors
As panders do and wittols? Cethus now
be crowned in history for a revenge,
Which in the former world wants precedent:
Methinks, as when the giants warred 'gainst heaven,
And dared for primacy with Jove himself ▪
He darting 'gainst their mountains thunderbolts ▪
Which shattered them to pieces: the war done,
I like the great Olympic Jupiter,
Walk o'er my ruins, tread upon my spoils
With majesty, I pace upon this floor
Paned with the trunks of Kings and potentates,
For what less could have sated my revenge?
This arch-rogue fallen amongst them? he whose eyes
Had the preposterous virtue to fire Troy.
Now is thy black soul for thy perjuries
Swimming in red damnation.

div.stage: Synon who had before counterfeited death, riseth up, and answereth.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Sir, not yet,
All policies live not in cethus brain,
Sinon hath share, and know if thou hast craft,
I have reserved some cunning: see my body
Free and untouched from wounds.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Speak, shall we then
Divide these dead betwixt us, and both live?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: If two suns cannot shine within one sphere,
Then why should two arch-villains? thou hast discovered
Projects almost beyond me, and for which
I have engrossed a mortal envy here,
I will be sole, or none.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: Cease then to be,
That I may live without competitor.
'Cause Sinon's name be erased out of the world,
And only mine remembered.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: Thine's but frailty,
My fame shall be immortal; made more glorious
In treading upon thee, as thou on these;
Stoop thou my underling.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: I still shall stand
sp.stage: They fight, and kill one another.
sp.l: Rooted.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: And yet cut down by Sinon's hand.

sp.speaker: Ceth.
sp.l: I now am dust like these.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.l: One single fight
Ends him, who millions ruined in one night.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Can you behold this slaughter?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.l: Yes, and die
At sight of it: for why should Helen live ▪
Helen the cause of all these prince's deaths ▪
Cease to lament, reach me my glass Hermione,
Sweet orphan do; thy father's dead already,
Nor will the fates lend thee a mother long.
sp.stage: Enter Hermione with a looking glass, then exit.
sp.l: Thanks, and so leave me. Was this wrinkled forehead
When 'twas at best, worth half so many lives?
Where is that beauty? lives it in this face
Which hath set two parts of the world at war,
Been ruin of the Asian monarchy,
And almost this of Europe? this the beauty
That launched a thousand ships from Aulis gulf?
In such a poor repurchase, now decayed?
See fair ones, what a little time can do;
Who that considers when a seed is sown,
How long it is ere it appear from th'earth,
Then ere it stalk, and after ere it blade,
Next ere it spread in leaves, than bud, than flower:
What care in watering, and in weeding took,
Yet crop it to our use: the beauties done,
And smell: they scarce last betwixt sun and sun ▪
Then why should these my blastings still survive,
Such royal ruins: or I longer live,
Then to be termed Helen the beautiful.
I am grown old, and death is ages due,
When courtiers sooth, our glasses will tell true.
My beauty made me pitied, and still loved,
But that decayed, the world's assured hate
Is all my dowry, than Helen yield to fate ▪
Here's that, my soul and body must divide,
The guerdon of adultery, lust, and pride.

sp.speaker: Vlys.
sp.l: In thee they are punished : of all these princes,
And infinite numbers that opposed Troy,
And came in Helen's quarrel (Save myself).
Not one survives, (Thanks to the immortal powers)
And I am purposed now to acquire by sea,
My kingdom and my dear Penelope,
And since I am the man solely reserved,
Accept me for the author's epilogue.
If he have been two bloody? 'tis the story,
Truth claims excuse, and seeks no farther glory,
Or if you think he hath done your patience wrong
(In tedious scenes) by keeping you so long,
Much matter in few words, he bade me say
Are hard to express, that lengthened out his play.

body.trailer: Here ends the whole history of the destruction of Troy.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
